content.text: Notes to Accounts — Reading the Fine Print

Notes to Accounts explain how the headline numbers in financial statements are calculated. They contain details about revenue recognition, expenses, loans, guarantees, lawsuits, and accounting methods.
Many risks are hidden in the notes, such as promoter guarantees, pending tax cases, or changes in depreciation methods. These do not appear clearly in profit numbers.
Example: A company shows profit of ₹500 crore, but in notes you find that ₹200 crore came from one-time land sale. This means real business profit is much lower.
Serious investors always read notes because this is where financial manipulation or hidden risks are usually visible.
